objdescid.compdate: c. 1789Some scholars have argued for a slightly earlier date for Blake's Tiriel manuscript and the wash drawings illustrating it, and hence by implication a slightly earlier date for all preliminary sketches for those wash drawings. See David Bindman, Blake as an Artist (Oxford: Phaidon, 1977) 43-44.

objinfo.medium: pencilThe inscription, lower right, by Frederick Tatham is in pen and ink.

provenance.name: Tate Collection
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; acquired by Frederick Tatham, probably at Catherine Blake's death in 1831; Tatham's brother-in-law, George Richmond; sold from Richmond's collection, Christie's, 29 April 1897, lot 147 with 21 other works, most by Blake and his brother Robert (£2.10s. to Richard Sisley); Sisley's daughter, Mrs. John Richmond, probably by gift or inheritance; given by Mrs. Richmond to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection) in 1922.

desc.objtitle:
Sketch for "Tiriel Supporting the Dying Myratana" (?),
object 1 (Butlin 200 recto)

objnote.p: Both the recto and verso pencil drawings on this leaf appear to be variant preliminary sketches for the monochrome wash drawing, Tiriel Supporting the Dying Myratana and Cursing His Sons (Butlin 198.1), an illustration to Blake's manuscript poem, Tiriel.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two groups of figures constitute this sketch. At left, at least two (perhaps three) figures form a triangular arrangement of overlapping bodies. The tallest leans diagonally to the right and appears to stretch its right arm in the same direction. This may be Tiriel. He may wear a hat or hood or have long hair. This figure may wear a gown and may support a second figure in the foreground who crouches or sits facing away from the viewer. This may be Tiriel's wife, Myratana. This figure's right arm may be outstretched to the right. Directly above this figure's arm, what may be a nude torso of a third figure is visible. On the right side of the composition, at least three figures stand facing forward and left. These are probably Tiriel's sons. The leftmost of these wears a gown and has short(?) hair. His left arm is bent at the elbow, and he holds an indeterminate object in his left hand. His right arm is extended vertically with right hand possibly clasped in a fist. To the right of this figure, a second figure who appears to wear a crown and gown also bends his left arm at the elbow. The head of a third figure is visible at far right, and though this figure is the least detailed, it too may have its left arm bent at the elbow. There are other lines and forms across the composition, but the significance of these is impossible to determine. The scene is likely connected with the monochrome wash drawing, Tiriel Supporting the Dying Myratana and Cursing His Sons (Butlin 198.1), an illustration to Blake's manuscript poem, Tiriel.

component.illusobjdesc: On the left side of the composition, at least two (perhaps three) figures form a triangular arrangement of overlapping bodies. The tallest leans diagonally to the right and appears to reach its right arm in the same direction. This may be Tiriel. He may wear a hat or hood or have long hair. This figure may wear a gown and may be supporting a second figure in the foreground. This figure is likely Tiriel in the act of cursing his sons at right.

A second figure is visible in the foreground at left who crouches or sits facing away from the viewer. This may be Tiriel's wife, Myratana. She may tilt her head sharply to the left. This figure's right arm may be outstretched to the right.

Between the outstretched right arms of the two figures at left, what may be a nude torso of a third figure is visible. The suggestion of breasts indicates the figure is likely female and thus perhaps identifiable as the dying Myratana.

On the right side of the composition, at least three figures stand facing forward and left. These are Tiriel's sons. The leftmost of these wears a gown and has short(?) hair. His left arm is bent at the elbow, and he holds an indeterminate object in his left hand. His right arm is extended vertically with right hand clasped in a fist(?).

On the right side of the composition, at least three figures stand facing forward and left. These are Tiriel's sons. The short-haired middle figure, who appears to wear a spiky crown and gown, bends his left arm at the elbow.

On the right side of the composition, at least three figures stand facing forward and left. These are Tiriel's sons. The head of a third figure is visible at far right, and though this figure is the least detailed, it too may have its left arm bent at the elbow and wear a gown.
